advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Micro Decision have been presented at the 1983 Hannover show.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert for Instructor 50, Byte March 1979, Page 45.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Adam Trinfo for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><i>Texas Instruments home computer, simply unbeatable</i> <br><br> Notice that the man seems not to feel at ease with a computer keyboard and still doesn't use the right finger...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles da Silva</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEMORY BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Vector Graphics also sold various cards for any S-100 systems. This one is a 8 Kb. static RAM card solded for $265 in kit version and $350 assembled.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART</strong></font><br><blockquote>This document compares the different Panasonic systems of the serie<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Choose from three computer systems:<br> The H-89 All-In-One Computer gives you everything in one compact, convenient unit.<br> The flexible H8 gives you the freedom to combine memory and interfacing for exactly the system you require.<br> And the powerful H11A gives you 16-bit power for your most complex programs.<br> The Heathkit line includes video terminals, matrix and letter quality printers, and accessories. You'll even find award-winning self-instruction packages to teach yourself programming in Basic or Assembly.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the only SILEX advert known so far... <br><br> It says : "Silex, a stone in our competitors garden." <br><br> Silex means flint in french, a stone mainly used in prehistoric times as tools and weapons. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This was probably the very first advert of the SC3000 as the pictured machine still was a Japanese version.<br> Notice that the price is in Australian$, probably without the Basic cartridge which is not mentioned in the advert. <br><br> The SC-3000 was very popular in New Zealand in the early to mid 80's. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You may not have thought of all the reasons for buying a personal computer. There are exciting games, of course, but what about financial management, household records, even income tax? You need a versatile, sophisticated machine that's as limitless as your imagination. You need the Compucolor ll...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
The ACE 2000 series consisted of three computers the 2000, 2100, and the 2200. The 2000 had no disk drives, the 2100 had one disk drive, and the 2200 had two disk drives. All featured a detachable keyboard, the same 1.02 MHz 65SC02 processor, the usual scattering of expansion slots around the motherboard and the half-height case.
Graphics modes and sound capabilities were in line with the Apple ][e. On the front panel, it had a row of LEDs for Power, Diagnostics, Double-high-res Graphics Mode, Hi-res Graphics Mode, and CPU Activity.
The back panel featured RS-232 serial ports (2), 1 DB-25 parallel port, 15-pin RGB video, and the power cable. The case and power supply had integrated fans. The case had the indentations for areas of expansion cards to poke out and provide new connectors; however, these expansion slots were not located in a nice row, 1-6. Slot 1 was missing (this was the parallel port on the back), slots 2 and 4 were combined into one slot (it was one or the other set via a jumper, not both), slot 3 was located near the rear and ran left to right, not from to back, slot 5 was located on the right side of the case and faced outward towards a screwplate covering the connector face and ran perpendicular to slot 3. Slot 6 was also missing, as it controlled the two disk drives.
Low-res graphics mode provided 16 colors in a 320x200 array, with a 2-4 line 'text window' at the bottom of the screen. Hi-res graphics gave you 512 x 384 pixels at either 4, 6, or 7 colors (depending on which software was used). There was supposedly another graphics mode, dubbed 'Double-High Resolution' which was supposed to give you 16 colors at 512x384, but there was a dearth of information about how to program in it.
The Franklins could run AppleSoft BASIC and DOS 3.3, but they shipped with the Franklin DOS 2 floppy FDOS 2. This allowed for such things as programmable function keys. Otherwise, there wasn't a whole lot different.
FDOS and BASIC were the keys to the enhanced graphics modes. If you had it, you could run Integer BASIC through a convoluted process. Booting Integer BASIC had an interesting secret: if you 'peeked' and 'poked' enough, you'd find the memory address for a reset. When Integer BASIC was reset, it displayed 'Apple ][' across the top of the screen. There were also numerous references to 'S. Wozniak' and 'S. Jobs' embedded in many of the programs Franklin delivered for it.
The Ace 2000 series was in fact the last Apple II compatibles made by Franklin. (~ 1987). Franklin then tried manufacturing PC clones before finally devoting themselves to pocket translators.
Thanks to Nathan Shrider for all this info.
computer.graphics: Same as Apple IIe + 512 x 384 in 4, 6, 7 or 16 colours
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke 90 keys with numeric keypad and 12 function keys
computer.name: ACE 2000
computer.ports: 2 x Serial RS-232, Parallel, RGB video, 3 x expansion slots

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> 64 KB RAM chips area<br> <b>(2)</b> 65SC02 processor<br> <b>(3)</b> Composite video output<br> <b>(4)</b> RGB video output<br> <b>(5)</b> Serial RS232 DB25 connector<br> <b>(6)</b> Apple II equivalent Slot 3<br> <b>(7)</b> Apple II slot 2 or 4 selectable by a jumper<br> <b>(8)</b> Joystick DB9 connector<br> <b>(9)</b> Apple II slot 5</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRANKLIN PC-8000</strong></font><br><blockquote>Another PC compatible system made by Franklin.<br> We have no information about it.</blockquote>
